error.text: I think it's good that Junge Freiheit allows us to 'enjoy' such reviews. Since I haven't swallowed any public media for years, I have a pretty good overview, which I also mix with that from other free media, of what Bärbel Bohley did shortly after the collapse of the GDR put into words.
The book is a gold mine, I ordered 3 copies and have already started reading. I will give away the other 2.

TS: Instead, refugees and migrants report in the article that they have received information that the border to Hungary is open to them. * There is no difference, only that was true. * After 30 years, however, there is a difference, at that time it was only about GDR refugees. *
Who is we? I was part of the 6 Day War, but definitely not here.
"Recently, there was also the question of which countries would potentially take in those who had been rescued and where they would be allowed to land first." Why is this question not clarified?

//The main thing is to build cheap houses, cheap t-shirts...// *sigh* okay, a little simpler: What you describe is allowed (use your money economically). What is described in the article is not allowed (do not tax income). Mixing the two is nonsense.

even mrs esken noticed that the refugees in turkey are well cared for. "We may also have to increase the support there, because the number of refugees who have been taken in by Turkey and who have been well accommodated and cared for by Turkey is constantly increasing." "migrants who want to cross the border" speak

>>"No, the pictures from the camps, which are double or triple overcrowded, are staged. Extra extras were hired. Do you actually believe what you write yourself?"<< Why do you try what I said to draw ridiculous? Because it's uncomfortable? And yes, of course I believe what I write and in most cases I know it, because knowing is better than "believing"

"No" to a transfer that would not be necessary, e.g. technical waste or cheap food from Europe. Even if Europe sometimes transfers a lot of money for this. But this does not go down well with the general public.

Quote: "My hair also stands on end at provocative comments that are about nothing but attention to what? For migration phobia. But again." What exactly do you mean by "migration phobia"? I don't understand.

Until "asylum applications" can only be made at EU embassies in the relevant countries. This would have several advantages; 1) Anyone who fears for their life and limb as a politically persecuted person would of course continue to flee in order to leave their country quickly. We should help these people directly, because the Geneva Refugee Convention and our fundamental right to asylum based on it apply only to them. 2) All others are "economic refugees" and therefore have time to wait for the decision on their "asylum application" or for papers for legal immigration in their home country. With their decision, they could then safely enter the EU without having to risk their necks and necks. I personally consider everything else to be inhumane and impractical.

In the immediate vicinity of Syria are countries like Jordan, Saudi Arabia and other rich and safe Gulf states where there is no war. In addition, in these countries the same religion and way of life is practiced from which the refugees come and to which they are used. I'm wondering why these people aren't looking for protection there, or why this protection isn't granted to them there...

In the future you will definitely have a new monetary and economic system. At the moment we have one where we always make sure that someone else earns enough from it. See trade fairs and hotel operators.

"But the western states with all their self-imposed, hypocritical code of values ​​have enough possibilities in their hands to reduce suffering and misery where it rages worst!" The problem is that many refugees come from countries that should actually be considered rich. They are rich in mineral resources. But there is corruption there and a few clans (I'll call it that now) siphon off all the riches. The West, which you criticize, has been moving billions of aid supplies to these countries for years. But if nothing fundamentally changes there, they will not help at all. I also wonder why the West is always held responsible for the weal and woe of these states. You are independent. You can decide for yourself. There was a lot of talk these days about the "responsible citizen", but that meant denying the people there their maturity. Maybe things would change if you completely stopped all interference and all help? I'm not asking this out of cynicism. But the last few decades have helped exactly nothing. Or do you want to march in there with soldiers? I would definitely refuse.
And our government wants to include half of the Balkans in the EU in the near future. Completely incomprehensible, Romania and Bulgaria should not have been included.

What has to happen happens. Whether a boat is full to overflowing is decided democratically. The majority says: the boat is far from full. If the majority is wrong and the boat then sinks, at least it may not have been wanted, but it was done right. That's comforting. In view of the majority in the German boat, I prepared to disembark and transfer to another boat. In between, I vote AfD and bother my relatives and acquaintances with dystopian doomsday scenarios á la Kassandra, which doesn't prevent them from supporting decent parties like CSU (for freedom and property), SPD (for social justice) and Greens (for the environment and the oppressed minorities ) to choose. Sweet consolation in my heart: I have done my duty. Even if it didn't work.

It doesn't look that simple further in the text: "Negotiations are currently underway at European level to organize the taking over of these children in a "coalition of the willing". "In this context, Germany is ready to take on an appropriate share," said the coalition with." It is nothing new to treat sick children from all over the world in Germany (sometimes even an accompanying person is allowed to accompany you), but after the treatment the children return home to their families. From time to time there is a report about such programs.
Hopefully we will read all of that in the next ZON article on this topic. Would be really good journalism.
If the heads of the authorities and the two lawyers haven't violated the law, then everything is cool. The right dumbass will scream either way, crucify them.

Not our problem. It's my problem when refugees have to live in inhumane conditions. So I'm not counting in your "our". ... pre-programmed poverty in old age of millions of Germans. You probably also hope that the others don't think "Not our problem." Solidarity is not a one-way street.

The children were already in Greece before the border attack. But it was not an issue and no public interest from the government side either. Now it is on the agenda. Why now ? Personally, I am of the opinion that Germany should not be abolished, but should be abolished.

"" In my opinion, Hamburg is a kind of special case politically - especially with regard to the SPD - and therefore not a good mood parameter. As a former judicial specialist and expert, you should know. Solution: You can only enter the country by plane via the embassy with a visa. The asylum application is decided by the decision-maker directly at the airport with yes or no. No Sea Watch, no tugs, no ugly pics, no dead, problem solved.

.....is a statement like "man needs water". Sounds plausible at first and it is difficult to say anything against it. Only: The water has to end up in the right channel for people too, because nobody needs water in their lungs.

Human rights apply to everyone, whether poor or rich, it doesn't matter of which origin, skin color, religion or other world view. For you, for me and for everyone else in the world. If you see things differently, you can ask yourself how you feel about our "human rights developed in the West"....

And of course combating the root causes of flight on the spot by means of goal-based support for development, education, health, etc. Clear distancing from corrupt states and, of course, immediate termination of all cooperation.

... had no foreign employees. At the moment, temporary workers are still in demand because they cost less. My father explained it to me like this: German specialists cost the company €60 an hour. But this does a great job. The temporary worker costs €20 an hour, but the work often needs to be improved. But that doesn't matter, because it's still only €40 for work done, not €60. You only need good specialists when things have to be done really quickly. (Perhaps explains the delay in some construction projects.)

Erdogan is not a toddler or a rebellious youth, Mr. Röttgen. If Erdogan wants to play, we should simply not play. Protect borders, support Greece and Bulgaria where possible, stop payments to Turkey. Just talk to Syria and Russia about how the refugees can be protected and cared for, fix guarantees and help for returnees.

Solidarity distribution of migrants to all EU countries! We have seen what this looks like in practice! In the current situation in which all of Europe finds itself, the admission of migrants can really not be an issue !!! In addition, when making a decision about admission, a strict distinction should be made between those who are actually entitled to asylum and economic migrants!

What's next? That, with regard to the sight of the houses in the GDR, manual skills were of little importance to the East Germans? The exact opposite is the case: with us everything is highly technical, only a few professions require real manual skills. A car mechanic from Syria really needs manual skills - he doesn't just exchange a part for a new one, he actually repairs it. It was the same in the GDR back then. Houses were not torn down and rebuilt, but really renovated. Have you ever considered that a woman who escaped being locked up (which is not very common in Syria, by the way) has some motivation to do something here? Our urban design aesthetic consists of factory-prefabricated parts, so there is no craftsmanship involved. Stonemasons only work on Cologne Cathedral (almost).

Calm down. It may well be that your favorite scenario "laissez fair, laissez passer" will become reality. If the virus does not die of its own accord in the next three months, it will spread so widely that all precautionary measures will become illusory and the state will have to capitulate. Then there are jobs with the undertakers, how nice. However, without protective clothing.

Yes, everything is clearer than light. The various offices for the protection of the constitution set up an artificial bugbear here, which is then “excavated” in a way that is effective for the media. And again and again the news says: “A police officer was there too! He has now been suspended from work.” Sure, he arranged the whole thing on behalf of his bosses and is now being given leave until the matter has grown stronger.

The only question is whether resignation would achieve anything at all. Maassen was dismissed because he was not loyal to the line and Haldenwang moved up because he did what his mistress ordered him to do like a little dog. The owner is the problem, not the puppy. A dismissal of Haldenwang would not change anything, because then someone would move up who would be even more loyal to the line. Only if Merkel were to be dismissed could there be a change in the direction of constitutionality, and the Haldenwang problem would then disappear of its own accord.

Germany is one of the largest pork producers and exporters in the world. And that is broken down as follows: Italy 17% Netherlands 11% Poland 10% South Korea 7.8% China 7.4% Austria 6.3% UK 5.3% Czech Republic 5.2% Romania 3.1% Greece 2.5 % Sweden 2.5% Denmark 2.3% Japan 2.3% France 2% Hungary 2% Slovakia 1.7% Philippines 1.5% Hong Kong 1.2% Ireland 1.1% Finland 0.92% Spain 0 .8% Belgium/Luxembourg 0.77% Bulgaria 0.72% South Africa 0.6% [...] Republic of the Congo 0.17% [...] Democratic Republic of the Congo 0.13% [...] Rest of Africa below 0.1% Source: [URL] Are you trying to tell me that this measly share of about 1% of German pork exports (to about 15% of the world population) is the cause of problems there and is driving people to ruin? For example, the largest African customer for German pork: South Africa population: over 58 million imported pork from Germany for 27.8 million dollars in 2017. That's pork for less than 50 cents per South African nose - in a whole year. That should "drive the local farmers into ruin"? Clear no.

And why shouldn't they stay in beautiful Turkey? Closer to home, Mohammedan country, same values, nice weather, great beaches, beautiful mountains, a model of democracy and human rights (therefore also an EU accession candidate actively supported with billions from Almanyah), and as the second strongest NATO army absolutely safe!

"In view of the rapid spread of the corona virus worldwide, immediate admission" of children who have fled is "urgent" write 50 Union MPs. Is it basically about children, including those who are accompanied by their parents or other relatives? The latter would then also have to be included. I couldn't find out how many that would be. There will probably be a lot of people, and presumably – and I hope so – 50 other MEPs will then protest against it. Or is it about children traveling alone? Then Germany can do it all on its own, a “coalition of the willing” is not needed for that. Because: “According to the latest available figures from the Greek government, only 7.5% of the 4,962 minors living in Greece without parents are under the age of 14. Fewer than 400 unaccompanied children, who would be distributed among all EU states willing to accept them." Maybe there are now more unaccompanied children, maybe 100? But Germany can also take on this on its own. There is financial and human support capacity.

The failed regime change in Venezuela triggered a huge wave of refugees. This, in turn, also had an adverse effect on neighboring countries, which themselves are struggling. Under DT, relations with Cuba and the countries of Central America deteriorated. But all this is already known and documented in detail. From the beginning DT spoke of caravans on the southern border. Of course, there were difficulties before, but during his tenure this problem has clearly and measurably worsened. It remains to be seen whether this refugee crisis can be overcome through a ruthless immigration policy combined with the mega-wall project without creating further turbulence. At the moment nobody wants to think about the possibility that the shifts in South and Central America could be the prelude to downright apocalyptic humanitarian catastrophes. Unfortunately, pointing out humanitarian values ​​is of little use at the moment. But bungle remains bungle. DT cannot cope with foreign policy and therefore endangers and burdens his own country to a large extent.

I don't know why we always have to pick on ourselves when we're doing good. We help people, we help children. Being unaccompanied as a child is also stressful and calls for action. Why should the sick always be preferred? Why should the healthy suffer the pressure of being alone until they are mentally ill and then, after their health has been ruined, come? What human dignity and what respect, what care is behind it? I think it's totally ok that the healthy aren't always discriminated against.
Quite simply, the right to asylum must be suspended or excluded in these cases. Otherwise, this proposal really makes no sense, you recognized that correctly.

For me, undeclared work is similar to corporate tax evasion. Anyone who (for whatever reason) is also de-solidarising should not whine in the crisis if they are not being supported by the community of solidarity.

If a system only works when there are more and more, then in the financial sector one speaks of a snowball system. As is well known, this only works up to a point where it collapses and is therefore forbidden. A society can only get younger if it keeps getting bigger or if the old are dying sooner. A school child already costs 1000 € per month. That corresponds roughly to a pensioner if you add the costs of the state for the parents because they receive child benefit and pay less tax. We must therefore become less and not more. The environment will thank us and then we can switch off power plants and give more land back to nature. The more migrants immigrate, the more daycare staff, teachers and doctors are needed.

Söder and Gabriel are completely torn apart like a caricature. But Seehofer actually comes off brilliantly. Angela plays the woman with the big heart and the responsibility for the big picture behind the professional and efficient facade. Seehofer plays the great politician who, in addition to his heart, takes responsibility for the office he has been given (and for this one in particular). There are other aspects as well, but Seehofer actually came across very positively in the film. Was that intentional?
